description: Whitelist for translation audit false positives. These are legitimate translations that trigger automated checks but are actually correct.

lengthOverflow.description: Translations that are legitimately shorter/longer than English due to language characteristics

rules.description: CJK languages (Chinese, Japanese, Korean) use more concise characters for technical terms
rules.rationale: CJK languages naturally use fewer characters for technical terms. E.g., 'Variables' (9 chars) → '変数' (2 chars) in Japanese is standard and complete.

rules.description: German creates compound words that are legitimately longer
rules.rationale: German compound words like 'Mathematik' and 'Schleifen' are standard translations, not UI overflow issues.

rules.description: Brand names and proper nouns remain in English across all languages
rules.rationale: Arduino is a brand name and should remain unchanged in all languages. Board names (Uno, Nano, Mega, ESP32) are product names and should also remain in English.

rules.description: Technical documentation URLs remain in English
rules.rationale: URLs to English documentation (e.g., GitHub wiki) should not be translated.

rules.description: Spanish translations naturally expand due to morphology
rules.rationale: Spanish 'Matemáticas' is the correct translation of 'Math'. Spanish technical terms often expand due to plural forms and morphological requirements.

rules.description: Error messages in CJK languages are naturally shorter due to character efficiency

examples.zh-hant: 請先選擇開發板 (Please select a board first), 缺少翻譯 (Missing translation)

rules.rationale: CJK error messages are legitimately 40-60% shorter than English due to character-based writing systems. Each character carries more semantic meaning than alphabetic words. These are complete, accurate translations, not truncated text.

rules.description: German translation of 'delay' is naturally shorter
rules.rationale: German 'Verzögerung' is the standard translation of 'delay' in programming contexts. While shorter than English, it is a complete and correct translation.

directTranslation.description: Translations that appear to be direct translations but are actually correct standard terminology

rules.description: Standard programming and electronics terms that have established translations
rules.rationale: These are standard technical terms with established translations. Word/character count similarity is expected for universal programming concepts. Includes basic math terms like 'number'.

rules.description: Words that are cognates or established loanwords in target language
rules.rationale: German and Spanish share Latin/Greek roots with English. Similar word forms are legitimate cognates, not lazy translations. German plurals often add -en (Sensor→Sensoren). Spanish technical terms often match English exactly due to shared Latin roots.

rules.description: Arduino API function names and technical terms that are standard translations
rules.rationale: Arduino API functions have established German and Spanish translations in educational contexts. These are standard terms used in Arduino education materials, not direct/lazy translations.

rules.description: Brand names used as category labels remain unchanged
rules.rationale: 'Arduino' is a registered brand name and should remain unchanged across all languages, even when used as a category label. This is consistent with international branding standards.

missingTranslation.description: Strings that legitimately remain in English

rules.description: CyberBrick 品牌名稱保留英文
rules.rationale: CyberBrick is a brand name that should remain in English across all languages to maintain brand recognition

rules.description: 國際通用技術縮寫保留英文
rules.rationale: LED, GPIO, PWM, I2C, LCD, UART, WiFi are internationally recognized technical acronyms that should not be translated

rules.description: 技術文件 URL 排除 missingTranslation 檢測
rules.rationale: HELPURL keys point to English technical documentation and should not be flagged as missing translations

rules.description: Brand names, product names, and proper nouns
rules.rationale: Brand names like 'Arduino' and product names like 'Uno', 'Nano', 'Mega', 'ESP32', 'Super Mini' should not be translated.

rules.description: Brand names used as category labels legitimately remain in English
rules.rationale: 'Arduino' is a registered brand name and should remain unchanged across all languages, even when used as a category label. This is consistent with international branding standards.

rules.description: Cognates that appear identical to English but are valid translations
rules.rationale: German 'Text' and Spanish 'Variables' are legitimate translations that happen to be identical to English. This is common for technical terminology derived from Latin.

rules.description: Programming language keywords and function names
rules.rationale: Arduino function names like 'setup' and 'loop' are part of the programming API and should remain in English.
URLs pointing to external English documentation should not be flagged as missing translations.

usage.description: How to use this whitelist in audit scripts
usage.implementation: Load this file in audit-translations.js and check each detected issue against whitelist rules before adding to report. If issue matches any whitelist rule, skip it or mark as 'whitelisted' with rationale.
usage.priority: Whitelist checks should run AFTER detection but BEFORE severity assignment to reduce noise in reports.

maintenance.addNewRules: When native speaker feedback indicates a legitimate translation is being flagged incorrectly
maintenance.removeRules: When actual translation errors are found that were previously whitelisted
